div1.p: Sweeney reports to Keeling on the material he has found concerning Reed's presentation, in 1900, to the American Public Health Association meeting, in Indianapolis.

div1.head: Memorandum from Ray Sweeney to Hal R. Keeling, January 23, 1948
div1.p: Memorandum to Hal Keeling
Here's my report on the Walter Reed research:
PHOTOGRAPHS:

Attached are two photos of the old German House, now known as the Athen-
aeum, procured from original negatives owned by W. H. Bass Photo Company,
308 South New Jersey Street. The shots were taken, as marked on the backs,
in 1905 and 1907. This was as close as I could get to the 1900 date. The
Indianapolis News showed me several shots of unknown date that looked just
a bit older, but they were in pretty poor shape to be reproduced.

There is available from Dr. Thurman B. Rice, 3167 North Delaware, a small
cut of the room at the Athenaeum in which Dr. Reed delivered his report.
It's 2 1/4 by 3 1/4 in size and is used in Dr. Rice's biography of Dr. J. N. Hurty
titled: “The Hoosier Health Officer”. The caption on this picture in the
book is: “It was in this room that Walter Reed read his paper. The room
was used for many years since as the meeting place of the Marion County
Medical Society”. It is not an extremely good photo for reproduction, but
shouldn't be too bad. The shot is from the back of an auditorium with rows
of seats to left and right, a small stage in front. Dr. Rice's secretary
says she will gladly loan the cut, which is now stored in the doctor's
basement.
REFERENCE BOOKS:

REPORTS AND PAPERS OF THE AMERICAN PUBLIC HEALTH ASSOCIATION, VOLUME XXVI,
pages 37 thru 53, a book available at the Indiana State Library which can-
not be removed from the premises. This contains “The Etiology of Yellow
Fever -- a Preliminary Note,” by Drs. Reed, Carroll, Agramonte and Lazear
as well as the entire proceedings, including discussions (apparently there
were none on the Reed paper) of the Indianapolis meeting in 1900.

REPORTS AND PAPERS OF THE AMERICAN PUBLIC HEALTH ASSOCIATION, VOLUME XXVIII,
page 375. This contains a report of the 30th annual meeting of the American
Public Health Association (Indianapolis was 28th) at New Orleans in 1902.
The proceedings at the morning session, December 12, contain a resolution
on the death of Reed. A nice eulogy - five paragraphs long. Book can't
be removed from Library.

INDIANA MEDICAL JOURNAL, OCTOBER, NOVEMBER ISSUES, 1900. October issue
contains an editorial calling the Association meeting in Indianapolis an
important event, says city will be hospitable, gives the street car routes
to various meeting places. Not much interesting information, in all.

November issue contains a general report on the meeting, including some
wordage on the Reed paper. This, however, is taken word for word from
the account in the Indianapolis “Journal” of October 24, 1900.

“THE HOOSIER HEALTH OFFICER;” a biography of Dr. J. N. Hurty, by Thurman
B. Rice, M. D. I have this book out of the State Library on a card. It
contains this reference to Dr. Reed on page 114:

“Up to this time nothing had been found to be of any benefit in combating
the dread yellow scourge, but better times were in the offing. In October,
1900, the American Public Health Association met at Indianapolis. Much
discussion of the Sanarelli organism was arranged for the regular program
of the meeting, but there was a surprise paper which was to become one of
the really great medical classics of all time.

A young army surgeon who had been assigned to leadership in the Yellow
Fever Commission came rushing in record time from headquarters in Cuba
to give his preliminary report on a new line of attack on the problem.
He was given a place on the platform though his paper was not on the
official program of the session. At the afternoon session of October 23,
1900, he spoke to about 150 physicians present in the old German House
(now the Athenaeum) at the intersection of Michigan and Alabama Streets.
The Indianapolis News of the following day has this to say of the event:

Surgeon Walter Reed, of the United States Army, who was sent to Cuba to
make a personal investigation of the yellow fever scourge, received per-
mission to read his paper, “Some Observations on the Yellow Fever in Cuba.”
The article was listened to with absorbing interest and the surgeon was
thanked by the Association.

The “Monthly Bulletin” of the Indiana State Board of Health for October,
1900, gives a synopsis of the papers and the meetings but makes no men-
tion of a paper by Walter Reed. That Hurty failed to realize the signif-
icance of this paper is further shown by the fact that no mention is made
in the Annual Report distributed a year later even though he did go into
considerable detail to tell of the meeting of the American Public Health
Association of the year before (1900). He does have the following to say
concerning the yellow fever, however (pp. 444-445):

Yellow fever. -- This subject came up for consideration before the general
sessions of the Association. It should be our duty to find out if the
Sanarelli bacillus is the organism accompanying this disease. The speaker
regarded the question as still open. It may belong to the “hog cholera
group.”

On page 457 of the Annual Report (1901) there are other references to
papers having to do with the etiology of yellow fever, but still no ref-
erence to Walter Reed or his epoch-making work. It will be seen from
this that those hearing the paper had no appreciation of its vast impor-
tance. As one reads the accounts of the time he is impressed with the
fact that the work of Sanarelli was much better received.
A synopsis of Dr. Reed's original paper and its conclusions is given:

The Etiology of Yellow Fever: A Preliminary Report by Reed, Carroll,
Agramonte and Lazear. (Trans. A. P. H. A. 1900, pp. 37-53.)

First: The work of Sanarelli was checked. No evidence was found that
B. icteroides is responsible for the disease. The germ was not found in
any of the cases examined, nor in any of the eleven cadavers dead of the
disease.

Second: The work of Dr. Carlos Finlay was checked. As early as 1881 he
had insisted that the mosquito was the vector. Also checked the work of
Dr. Henry R. Carter, who had noted a set interval of time between the
first case in a community and the secondary cases.

Third: Dr. Reed gives the details of the story, now so well known, and
describes in detail the case of Dr. James Carroll, who was voluntarily
inoculated by permitting himself to be bitten by a mosquito which had
previously bitten a known case. Dr. Carroll developed tropical yellow
fever but recovered. He also tells the story of the case of Dr. Jesse
Lazear, who likewise was bitten and who died of the disease -- a glorious
martyr to science, medicine and the welfare of mankind.

Conclusions: ‘(1) Bacillus icteroides (Sanarelli) stands in no causative
relation to yellow fever, but when present should be considered as a sec-
ondary invader in this disease. (2) The mosquito serves as the intermed-
iate host for the parasite of yellow fever.’"

NEWSPAPERS
“STAR”

Here is the story (front page) from the Indianapolis “Star”, October 12,
1933 on the memorial banquet held to celebrate the Reed talk in 1900.
It was headlined: “Health Leaders Honor Heroes of Fever Conquest” and
the lead was largely about four men -- one of them a Hoosier -- who were
the guests of honor. As the story picks up ...

"They were among the 21 men who voluntarily submitted themselves to in-
noculation with the yellow fever agent carried by the mosquito, to assist
Dr. Walter Reed, deceased, of the United States Army, to whose memory
tribute was paid by those attending the dinner.

Several of the speakers pointed out that it was 33 years ago this month
that Major Reed, in a paper read before the same association in a con-
vention in Indianapolis, successfully routed opponents who contended that
the fever was transmitted by something other than the mosquito...

... The reading of the honor roll by Dr. King at the banquet followed a
complete account of the work of Major Reed and his associates in proving
definitely that the mosquito was the carrier of the transmitting agent.
Those who traced his work last night were Major General Robert U. Patterson,
Surgeon General of the U.S. Army, and General Frederick F. Russell, direc-
tor of the international health division, Rockefeller Foundation, New York ...

... Had it not been for the work of Major Reed and his colleagues, Dr.
Pratt said, yellow fever deaths during the World War would have numbered
500,000 instead of the 1,500 who fell victims to the disease ...

... Hundreds of messages paying tribute to Major Reed were received from
Army officers and civilians from all parts of the country. There was a
storm of applause when Dr. John A. Farrell, retiring president, read the
following letter from President Roosevelt:

“I have just learned that your association will hold a memorial session
to Dr. Walter Reed on Wednesday evening, October 11, 1933 at Indianapolis.
This nation today shares with the world untold benefits to human health
resulting from the monumental work of Dr. Walter Reed, United States Army.
In definitely establishing the fact that the mosquito is the transmitting
agency of yellow fever, he earned the gratitude of humanity. I take great
pleasure in joining you in honoring the memory of this great American.”
“TIMES”

The Indianapolis “Times” of October 12, 1933 has a page 4 story headed
“Public Health Workers Honor Dr. W. F. King” which is just a short version
of the Star coverage, except the Times refers to the 18 men who submitted
to the yellow fever tests in Cuba.
“NEWS”

The Indianapolis “News”, October 12, 1933, carried a second-day-lead story
headed “Health Groups Turn to Hygiene”. There is no mention of Reed.

RANDOM FACT ON GERMAN HOUSE: the real estate was purchased in 1892 (135'
by 203') at the corner of New Jersey and Michigan streets. Ground was
broken in 1893 for the first of the buildings. It was completed in '94.
The other buildings of the group were finished in '97 and '98.

I have tried, without success, to locate any witnesses to Dr. Reed's talk.
Dr. Thurman Rice doesn't seem to feel that there are any of them still
around. Several other doctors contacted believe there might be and sug-
gest the name of some old-timer they know. However, the old-timer says
no and suggests an older-timer. More work could be done on this phase of
the problem, however -- a lot of people have names to suggest.

Where Reed stayed in Indianapolis is a complete mystery -- no progress
at all.

As for Dr. Hench's inquiry on “lower auditorium” vs. “amphitheater” --
I think we can safely assume they are the same. I note that Dr. Rice, in
his book, calls it a “room” but the room pictured is obviously an auditor-
ium.
